byline.original: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: ''Do you know any doctors who can keep their patients on a leash?'' asked Dr. Jay Alexander, a Chicago cardiologist. ''It was not my recommendation to Mike.''
docs.snippet: LEAD: ''Do you know any doctors who can keep their patients on a leash?'' asked Dr. Jay Alexander, a Chicago cardiologist. ''It was not my recommendation to Mike.''

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE phenomenon is familiar in the world of ''hackers'': a young man of exceptional intelligence, feeling that he is alienated from the system and threatened by the real world, finds safety in the computer lab and develops an obsession for the technology. Shunning sleep, and limiting social relationships to the sphere of hackers with whom he shares his obsession, he pushes himself to his physical and mental limits in the quest for the ultimate hack, the fusion of elegant thought and computer code.

headline.main: Health; Exercise Alone May Not Help Cholesterol Level, Study Says

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Exercise may enhance an important form of blood cholesterol, but only because it causes people to lose weight, a new study indicates.
docs.snippet: LEAD: Exercise may enhance an important form of blood cholesterol, but only because it causes people to lose weight, a new study indicates.

headline.main: Boulder Journal; Therapists Offer Relief by Putting Patient on the Right Scent

byline.original: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: His nerves were jangled and his back was aching, but Greg Taft knew just the remedy. He hurried off to see his aroma therapist.
docs.snippet: LEAD: His nerves were jangled and his back was aching, but Greg Taft knew just the remedy. He hurried off to see his aroma therapist.
